ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Noise-Induced Hearing Loss (Asymmetric)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of factory work and right-handed rifle shooting explains the high-frequency loss and asymmetry (left ear more exposed).

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Retrocochlear Pathology (e.g., Vestibular Schwannoma)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Suspected due to asymmetric SNHL, unilateral tinnitus, and aural fullness, but ruled out by normal MRI and ABR.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To determine degree, type, and configuration of hearing loss.
To assess speech reception thresholds and word recognition abilities.
To assess retrocochlear pathway integrity given asymmetry.
QuickSIN to evaluate signal-to-noise ratio loss and need for assistive technology.
To determine upper limits of comfort for hearing aid programming.
COSI to identify specific patient needs and goals.
To verify hearing aid gain matches prescriptive targets.
To validate that amplified sounds are perceived at appropriate loudness levels.
To ensure hearing aids meet manufacturer specifications.
To assess subjective benefit with hearing aids.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial evaluation revealed bilateral asymmetric sensorineural hearing loss, worse in the left ear, with high-frequency sloping configuration. Middle ear function was normal. Acoustic reflexes were elevated or absent, consistent with the degree of loss or potential retrocochlear pathology. The asymmetry and unilateral symptoms (tinnitus, fullness) constitute red flags requiring medical referral.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Right: Normal sloping to moderately severe SNHL. Left: Normal sloping to severe SNHL. Asymmetric configuration.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRT aligned with PTA. WRS excellent in Right (92%) and good in Left (80%).

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Ipsilateral normal to absent; Contralateral mostly absent. Consistent with cochlear loss or retrocochlear pathology.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Medical evaluation performed by Otology to rule out retrocochlear pathology. ABR and MRI were ordered and results were normal. Patient cleared for amplification.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: waves I-V latencies normal bilaterally, 90 dBnHL, no dysfunction

tests.name: MRI of internal auditory canal
tests.result_summary: normal internal auditory canals bilaterally, clear of pathology

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Patient returned after medical clearance (normal MRI and ABR). Pre-fitting evaluation showed a moderate SNR loss on QuickSIN, suggesting hearing aids alone may be insufficient in noise. LDLs were normal, and COSI goals were established focusing on TV, restaurants, and grandchildren.

tests.name: Loudness Discomfort Levels (LDLs)
tests.result_summary: Normal range at all frequencies tested.

tests.name: Self-report scale
tests.result_summary: COSI goals: Hearing wife in restaurants, hearing grandchildren, hearing TV.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Hearing aid fitting performed with bilateral RIC devices. Real-ear measures verified gain to NAL-NL2 targets. Aided loudness judgments confirmed appropriate perception of soft, comfortable, and loud sounds. Verification of electroacoustic performance and directional microphones was completed.

tests.name: Real-Ear Measures (REM)
tests.result_summary: Verified to NAL-NL2 targets; inputs 50, 65, 80 dB SPL provided appropriate gain.

tests.name: Aided Loudness Judgments
tests.result_summary: Patient rated speech signals appropriately (Soft, Comfortable, Loud but okay).

tests.name: RESR90
tests.result_summary: Performed at 90 dB SPL; patient did not report loudness discomfort.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Two-week follow-up assessment. Patient reported doing well but still having difficulty in noise. Adjustments were made to high-frequency gain and noise reduction. Aided testing demonstrated significant improvement.

tests.name: Aided COSI
tests.result_summary: Patient reported hearing 'better' or 'much better' in listening environments compared to unaided.

tests.name: Aided QuickSIN
tests.result_summary: SNR Loss of 6 dB (mild loss), significantly improved from 14 dB unaided.

tests.name: 2cc coupler measurement
tests.result_summary: Electroacoustic analysis performed at user settings to serve as a baseline.

proposed_items: Referral to Otology for medical evaluation of asymmetry
counseling_actions: Explanation of asymmetric hearing loss and need for medical clearance
Counseling on realistic expectations in noise based on QuickSIN results
Instruction on hearing aid use, care, and maintenance
Demonstration of Multi Mic and iPhone app streaming features

escalation.rationale_short: Mandated referral to rule out retrocochlear pathology (e.g., vestibular schwannoma) given asymmetric symptoms.

follow_up_plan.objective: Assess benefit, fine-tune settings, and perform electroacoustic analysis.

expected_outcome: Aided QuickSIN: SNR Loss of 6 dB (mild loss), significantly improved from 14 dB unaided.
Aided COSI: Patient reported hearing 'better' or 'much better' in listening environments compared to unaided.
Subjective report: Patient reported hearing significantly better and found the Multi Mic to be a significant help.
2cc coupler measurement: Electroacoustic analysis performed at user settings to serve as a baseline.
